description:
Hitomi Kanzaki is in a very depressed mood. She only wants to sleep and fade away. Her misery summons Lord Folken who sends her to Gaea. The people of Gaea think she is the Wing Goddess, who can call upon the legendary Dragon Armor called Escaflowne. On Gaea, King Van, the sole survior of the White Dragon Clan, is also in a depressed state. Swearing an oath to get his revenge on the Black Dragon Clan that oblierated Van's kingdom, he lives by the sword. Now that the Wing Goddess has finally appeared, she posseses Gaea's world fate in her heart. Escaflowne will either lead Gaea to peace or total ruin.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Isekai
tags.description: Features characters being transported into an alternate world setting and having to adapt to their new surroundings.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

node.description:
__Favorite Colors:__ Pink, brown
__Hobbies:__ Performing, reading, singing

[Official Website](http://www.jvcmusic.co.jp/maaya/) | [LINE Blog](https://lineblog.me/sakamotomaaya/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/maayasakamotoCh) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maaya_Sakamoto) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%9D%82%E6%9C%AC%E7%9C%9F%E7%B6%BE)

Married frequent costar [Kenichi Suzumura](https://anilist.co/staff/95005) on August 8, 2011.

Kanno's earliest experiences with music came from attending church with her parents. She studied keyboard from a young age on both the piano in her home and the organ at her kindergarten. In elementary school, she began participating in composition contests, but in high school, Kanno began to take more of an interest in literature than in music.

She attended Waseda University, where she majored in literature, but she transcribed music for various student groups at Waseda in her free time. While in university, Koei, a Japanese video game company, asked her to compose the soundtrack to Nobunaga's Ambition. The game turned out to be a hit, and Kanno's music career was launched.

Kanno has also composed music for artists such as [Maaya Sakamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/95090/), [Megumi Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/96105/) and [Kyouko Koizumi](https://anilist.co/staff/164646/). She is also a keyboardist, as well as the frontwoman for [Seatbelts](https://anilist.co/staff/193673/), who perform many of Kanno's compositions and soundtracks.

She has collaborated with directors [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) and [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) multiple times.

In addition to Japanese, she speaks a little English and some French.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1521695330)

Currently working as a freelancer, having previously worked for [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/) and [D.A.S.T.](https://anilist.co/studio/6255/)

Yuuki graduated from Saitama Prefectural Toda Shoyo High School and has been active in the school's "Manga and Anime Research Interest Club.” He found business in the National Health Insurance but couldn't give up on being an animator, so he left and became an animator instead. Has collaborated with director [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/) many times, including on his most famous work, [The Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/).

He works on doujinshi under the circles The Man in the High Castle and Ubik, both references to the works of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick. The published doujinshi include key animation from his body of work and specially drawn manga. On the other hand, since he worked on Ralphilia Saga by [Akara Arisato](https://anilist.co/staff/149449/), he has been involved in several works as a guest member of the doujin circle La Moon.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. His projects are usually noted to contain strong themes of love, war, spirituality or mysticism, and ecological concern.

Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/staffwhy)

__Birthplace:__ Tokyo, Japan

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%BA%9D%E5%8F%A3%E8%82%87) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Mizoguchi)

Hajime Mizoguchi is a Japanese cellist and composer.

Mizoguchi started playing piano at the age of 3, and the cello at the age of 11. From 1978-1985 he attended the Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music where he majored in violoncello. In 1986, he released his first album, Half Inch Dessert, being listed as composer, arranger, and performer. From that time on, he has released more than 20 albums including motion picture soundtracks.

His compositions include soundtracks to works such as [Jin-Roh](https://anilist.co/anime/570/) and [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/南雅彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masahiko_Minami)

A founder and representative director of studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/). Also the leading producer of its Studio B.

After graduating from Osaka University of Arts, Minami joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) in 1984. There he did desk work and served as a production assistant on many of [Masuo Ueda](https://anilist.co/staff/148840/)'s productions. He was promoted to producer on [Musha Knight Commando](https://anilist.co/anime/9087/) in 1991, and from there he went on to produce shows such as [Mobile Fighter G Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/96/), [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/) and [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/). In 1998, he left Sunrise and established Bones with [Toshihiro Kawamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/103531/) and the late [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). He was elected as the representative director of the studio and has held the position since.

Minami's classmates at university included [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Hiroyuki Yamaga](https://anilist.co/staff/100988/), and [Kazuhiko Shimamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/97479/). He appears as a character in the manga [Aoi Honoo](https://anilist.co/manga/55292/), which Shimamoto wrote about his own university days. The manga also received a TV drama adaptation, in which Minami was portrayed by actor Kaname Endou.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sekise10) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yutaka_nakamura) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/中村豊_(アニメーター%29)

Yutaka Nakamura graduated from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin and first joined studio Ad Cosmo. After switching several studios; from Art Office Sharaku, to Anime Torotoro, to [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), he eventually settled at [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/) with a contract.

Nakamura is considered to be among the best action animators, with his scenes featuring catchy movement and effects. Some of his recognizable traits include camera shaking, blurs, and bending and stretching high-speed objects. His fights are praised for its weighty, intense choreographies that are heavy on impact frames. His signature trait is drawing debris as simple cubes, consequentially named "Yutapon Cubes," which are stylistic and easy to draw. Despite being responsible for popularizing it, Nakamura has stated that he started doing it when he noticed [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) doing it. 

(Source: Animators Wiki)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/772463158506106881)

Akane worked at [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) for the first 15 years of his career. There he collaborated with [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) to direct his most famous work, [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/). After having left Sunrise in 2000, he joined [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/), where he created and directed the shows [Geneshaft](https://anilist.co/anime/909/), [HeatGuy J](https://anilist.co/anime/958/), and the most famous of the three, [Noein: To Your Other Self](https://anilist.co/anime/584/).

Since then Akane has gone freelance. His more recent works include [Birdy the Mighty: Decode](https://anilist.co/anime/3974/) and [Stars Align](https://anilist.co/anime/104052/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/772463158506106881)

Akane worked at [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) for the first 15 years of his career. There he collaborated with [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) to direct his most famous work, [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/). After having left Sunrise in 2000, he joined [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/), where he created and directed the shows [Geneshaft](https://anilist.co/anime/909/), [HeatGuy J](https://anilist.co/anime/958/), and the most famous of the three, [Noein: To Your Other Self](https://anilist.co/anime/584/).

Since then Akane has gone freelance. His more recent works include [Birdy the Mighty: Decode](https://anilist.co/anime/3974/) and [Stars Align](https://anilist.co/anime/104052/).

As a teenager Yamashita was influenced by the works of [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) and [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/), and was inspired to become an animator.

After graduating from Kurashiki Minami High School, he moved to Tokyo to become an animator and joined Bevore. After Bevore's dissolution, he joined Atelier Giga, and from there he joined Project Team Muu. There he was jointly in charge of the character designs, animation direction and storyboards for [Giant Robo the Animation: The Day the Earth Stood Still](https://anilist.co/anime/2321/). The production took nearly 10 years, during which Yamashita gave it his all. After the production was over he started losing his motivation for animation. Though, it sparked again, after having met [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/) on the opening animation for a video game called, Gensou Suikogaiden. 

In 2001, Yamashita worked as a key animator on [Spirited Away](https://anilist.co/anime/199/), a [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) feature film. There he was in charge of multiple scenes, most notably Chihiro and Haru's free fall at the end of the movie. This earned him high high praise from [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), and he was thus selected as one of the animation director's for [How's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/). Since then he has served as an animation director on most of Ghibli's movies.

In 2018, Yamashita directed "The Invisible Man," a short film part of the anthology collection [Modest Heroes](https://anilist.co/anime/103887/), produced by [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/). The film won the Newcomer's Award in the Animation Division at the 22nd Japan Media Arts Festival

Married to [Miho Shimogasa](https://anilist.co/staff/116279/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/亀山俊樹)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐々木史朗_(音楽プロデューサー%29) | [Flying Dog](https://www.jvcmusic.co.jp/flyingdog/)

The founder of record label [flying DOG](https://anilist.co/studio/464/flying-DOG).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hiroshikoujina)

The representative director of Studio Live.
Married to [Asako Nishida](https://anilist.co/staff/111163/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/asakonishida) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/24387) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西田亜沙子)

Originating from Studio Muu.


Married to fellow animator [Seiichi Nakatani](https://anilist.co/staff/107409/Seiichi-Nakatani).
Originating from [Tezuka Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/200/), currently affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).
Originating from [Tezuka Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/200/), currently affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).
He was originally part of Studio Live, but in 1995 switched over to Studio Fantasia.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1522114648098619397)

He grew up admiring anime such as [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/) an during highschool he started animating with his friends. He enrolled into a professional animation school after graduating but quit quickly due to being disappointed in how the lessons were conducted.

He joined Anime R and later its subsidiary Studio Muu. His first work was as an in-betweener on [Psycho Armor Govarian](https://anilist.co/anime/6428/) while his debut as a key animator was on [Captain Tsubasa](https://anilist.co/anime/2116/).

After working on [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/)'s [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) he permanently joined Production I.G. becoming known, together with [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/) and [Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/), as "The Three Gods of I.G."

He's is one of the most prominent animators of the realist school, with emphasis on solid shapes and weighty character animation.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ynaritaka)

Originating from [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大久保徹)

Affiliated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).
